required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Endoscopic Treatment of Bronchial Carcinoid Tumors
clinical_study.official_title: Feasibility and Therapeutic Method of Endoscopic Treatment of Bronchial Carcinoid Tumors: 22 Years Experience of Saint-Etienne

lead_sponsor.agency: Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Saint Etienne

clinical_study.source: Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Saint Etienne

brief_summary.textblock: Carcinoid tumors of the lung are considered to be a low-grade malignancy. Surgical resection is considered the standard approach. Recent data has shown that a complete endoscopic treatment could be considered. An endoscopic treatment is can be a alternative to invasive surgery.

detailed_description.textblock: The objective of this study is to evaluate the feasibility and therapeutic method of endoscopic treatment of bronchial carcinoid tumors.

primary_outcome.description: patients who have a complete endoscopic treatment

secondary_outcome.description: Analysis type of endoscopic method used.
Analysis the deadline before recurrence of the tumor.

arm_group.description: Patient with endoscopic treatment will be included. Some medical data collection by medical record will be collected.

intervention.description: Medical data collection by medical record will be collected: demographics data, medical history, clinical symptoms, smoking, type of endoscopic method, complete treatment or not, type of surgeries if yes, anatomopathology of the injury and recurrence if yes

study_pop.textblock: Patients treated by endoscopic approach for a carcinoid tumor will be included.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients treated by endoscopic approach for a carcinoid tumor at the University Hospital Centre of Saint-Etienne between November 1995 to December 2017.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients treated for a recurrence of carcinoid tumor.
- Patients with metastatic disease.
